title: How to Remove Car Battery Terminals

steps.title: Open the hood of the car and use the support bar to prop it open.
steps.content: Open the hood of the car and use the support bar to prop it open. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Locate the battery within the engine compartment.
steps.content: Locate the battery within the engine compartment. If you're unsure about which part is the battery, then check your ownerâ€™s manual. Some vehicles have their battery in the trunk, under or behind an access panel.

steps.title: Check the positive post to be sure that the cover is on.
steps.content: Check the positive post to be sure that the cover is on. If the post is not covered, place a towel or other clean rag over the positive post. This will help you to avoid accidentally creating sparks by coming into contact with the positive terminal.

steps.title: Loosen the nut that holds the terminal onto the negative post using a socket wrench.
steps.content: Loosen the nut that holds the terminal onto the negative post using a socket wrench. The nut will be located to the left of the terminal. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Lift the terminal off the negative battery post.
steps.content: Lift the terminal off the negative battery post. If needed, pry the terminal open with a screwdriver, or gently wiggle the connector until it loosens.

steps.title: Remove the cover from the positive post.
steps.content: Remove the cover from the positive post. [3] X Research source Loosen the nut that holds the terminal onto the positive post by using a socket wrench. Although the negative terminal has been removed, still be careful to ensure the wrench used does not contact any other metal.

steps.title: Lift the terminal off the positive post.
steps.content: Lift the terminal off the positive post. If needed, pry the terminal open with a screwdriver or wiggle the connector to loosen the terminal.

steps.title: Sprinkle the terminals with baking soda.
steps.content: Sprinkle the terminals with baking soda. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Scrub the terminals and the posts using a special battery terminal brush, inexpensive and available at most auto parts store.
steps.content: Scrub the terminals and the posts using a special battery terminal brush, inexpensive and available at most auto parts store. This special brush has two parts, one to fit over the battery posts and another to fit inside the cable terminals. A battery terminal brush is specially designed for this job and will eliminate the need to use your fingers for cleaning. In a pinch, any wire or bristled brush will do, but, a small one will work best inside the terminals. If your brush will not fit into the interior of the terminals, try an old toothbrush or, as a last resort, use a rag draped over your finger to scrub inside each terminal.

steps.title: Rinse the terminals and posts with clean water.
steps.content: Rinse the terminals and posts with clean water. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Dry the terminals and posts with a clean towel or rag.
steps.content: Dry the terminals and posts with a clean towel or rag.

steps.title: Rub petroleum jelly onto the posts.
steps.content: Rub petroleum jelly onto the posts. The petroleum jelly will help to prevent future corrosion from building up. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Place the positive terminal back onto the positive post.
steps.content: Place the positive terminal back onto the positive post. [7] X Research source

steps.title: Hand-tighten the nut until you can no longer turn it.
steps.content: Hand-tighten the nut until you can no longer turn it.

steps.title: Place a socket wrench over the nut and tighten the nut until it no longer turns.
steps.content: Place a socket wrench over the nut and tighten the nut until it no longer turns. Although the negative terminal is not connected, still be careful to ensure the wrench used does not contact any other metal.

steps.title: Place the cover over the positive post.
steps.content: Place the cover over the positive post. If the cover is missing, then you should cover the post with a clean towel or a rag.

steps.title: Place the negative terminal back onto the negative post.
steps.content: Place the negative terminal back onto the negative post. Hand-tighten the nut until you can no longer turn it.

steps.title: Place a socket wrench over the nut and turn it until the nut is completely tightened.
steps.content: Place a socket wrench over the nut and turn it until the nut is completely tightened.

steps.title: Remove all tools, towels or rags from the engine area.
steps.content: Remove all tools, towels or rags from the engine area.

steps.title: Lower the support bar and close the hood.
steps.content: Lower the support bar and close the hood.

steps.title: Discard any rags or towels that came into contact with battery acid.
steps.content: Discard any rags or towels that came into contact with battery acid.
